writingDetail.html:
Hi everyone, this is Sam Black with Drafting Archetypes,

and today I'm going to be talking about blue control in Dusk Mourn.

As always,

the notes are available to follow along at patreon.com/draftingarchetypes.

So last weekend I won $2,000

in the Arena Open drafting heavily blue decks in both drafts,

going 4-0 in both drafts,

and I'm finding myself increasingly gravitating toward blue in the format,

which should come as no surprise given my preferences in every format,

and the fact that blue is actually very good in this format.

So I want to talk about how to draft a specific flavor of blue deck that I think of as kind of the spiritual successor to the Demir/X-Color Demir decks in Strixhaven and the Bargain Blue decks in Wilds of Eldraine,

also known as just kind of how I draft, really.

Once I've figured a set out, once left my own devices.

I guess it's also something that I was doing with the blue Fountainport Valdaxx in Bloomberg Euro.

This is just kind of like,

I think what I'm sort of always working toward figuring out how to get away with in any given set.

So blue in this set has a really solid foundation in its best commons,

where Unable to Scream and Vanish from Sight is like your cheap removal spell and expensive removal spell that a lot of colors usually have these days,

but where the cheap removal spell, Unable to Scream,

is very cheap and answers big stuff, it comes with vulnerabilities.

This is the Enchant creature for a blue that makes the Enchant creature a 0/2 that loses all abilities.

So it has the vulnerabilities that they still have an object and it's an enchantment and there are reasonable cards that destroy enchantments in this set.

So you can get punished, but you've only invested one mana,

you're taking away the text of the creature which is really big,

and it's an enchantment and there are a lot of enchantment synergies so you often get paid just for casting it.

So that card's very good.

And then Vanish from Sight, the more expensive removal spell,

is not a permanent answer,

because it only puts it on top of their library,

but the bonus surveil one over the kind of stock version of this effect is very nice and being able to hit nonland permanents rather than just creatures is also very nice.

So it's a very good version of an effect that's always a little bit underrated and there are ways to mill your opponent to turn it into hard removal and it also just like having like clean instant speed 1 for 1s is something Blue is very looking for because you also have good card advantage,

which I will get to, but I also want to touch on Meat Locker,

the 2 in a Blue room that taps a creature and puts 2 stun counters on it.

As its own card, so Divorced from Drowned Diner,

the card draw side of that room,

Meat Locker is a remarkably good short-term answer,

but I've been impressed by how much it matters to be able to lock a creature down for a while.

It's not as good as Tumble Magnet,

which is a 3-mana artifact that can tap to tap something,

but it comes with 3 counters and you have to remove a counter to tap something,

because it has to tap the same thing,

but it's more of a card by itself than it looks like it is.

When your deck is short on removal but you have some Meat Lockers,

it means that you do have ways to find,

if there's a giant creature that you need to deal with,

there's a card that you can draw that will deal with it while you figure out another answer or while the game ends or whatever.

Those 3 removal spells pair with 2 good common card draw spells in Glimmer Burst,

the 4 mana draw to make a Glimmer instant, and Drowned Diner,

the other room that's attached to Meat Locker, 5 mana draw, 3 discard 1.

Both of those cards are very good,

and so I'm happy to have a lot of card draw in my deck.

Remarkably often Glimmer Burst gets to be a not very tempo negative 3 for 1.

If you ever block a 2/1 or 3/1 with the Glimmer and draw 2 cards,

you're just so far ahead.

You've probably spent more mana than they spent,

but you got to draw 2 cards out of the deal and dealt with their card that they had actually invested some amount of mana in.

Also,

if not much is happening and you get a 1/1 that represents some kind of board presence,

maybe gets to attack or whatever, that's pretty nice.

The object is quite good.

It also means that it's triggering your eerie stuff because the Glimmer is an enchantment.

So notably, Unable to Scream, Meat Locker/Drowned Diner,

and Glimmer Burst are all enchantments, all trigger eerie.

So you have this very good foundation of card draw and removal in blue that is synergistic with a lot of different stuff.

If you just have a bunch of that, you have most of a reasonable game plan.

Then you can back that up with Tunnel Surveyor and Stocked Researcher,

which give you a good curve of early blue defensive creatures.

Tunnel Surveyor is the 3 mana 2G that makes a 1/1 Glimmer,

and Stocked Researcher is the 2 mana 3/3 that can only attack if you've had an enchantment to enter.

Neither of those cards are anything special,

but once we're down to the fifth and sixth best blue cards or whatever,

I think it's showing some reasonable depth to the number of blue cards that you're happy to play in this kind of deck.

They both are very good at blocking against the aggressive decks to give you time for your card draw spells and to give you the ability to be a little bit more discerning in what you're going to do with your removal.

You don't need to answer every random manifest if you can block with a Stocked Researcher or Tunnel Surveyor.

And then Twisted Reality is a good counterspell.

This is the 1 blue blue counterspell or manifest.

It's a hard counter, like it's cancel plus,

but the plus is particularly good because it cancels at its worst when you're behind on board and you need something that's going to affect the battlefield instead of just like a counterspell.

And so in a pinch you can manifest and get a blocker.

Also if you just have a lot of stuff to spend your mana on,

it's like safe to pass the turn with a counterspell and then if your opponent doesn't do anything and you don't want to just like not use that three mana that turn because you have,

you know, stuff that you're going to spend your mana on on future turns,

then you can manifest and not be down the mana.

So it's among the best like cancels for limited ever,

even including like uncommon cancels.

And finally, Daggerclaw Megalodon, the land cycler,

is nothing to write home about, doesn't have like great stats or anything,

but a six mana 5/7 Vigilance is not at all embarrassing.

Like it blocks basically everything and it has vigilance so it's like a passable finisher that's like can make progress on killing your opponent while still playing defense.

I've also,

I played one match that is best of three where I saw my opponent's whole deck and they were like red green with only one,

or maybe they were green something and they only had,

I think they're actually green black and they only had like one hard removal spell in their deck and they had just like a bunch of five fours and stuff.

So I realized that if there was like a Megalodon in play they would just not,

like their cards wouldn't work anymore.

So I just like cited in a couple of Megalodons and that plan worked.

So it's nice that there's a common that goes very late that's relatively cheap to put in your deck because you can cycle it if you have to that gives you a finisher in this color that's mostly good at card draw and removal and can sometimes have problems ending a game in a meaningful way that I'm going to talk about a little bit in more in more detail later.

So by itself blue can kind of cover everything you need and mono blue itself per seventh year per untapped is like drafted one percent of the time which is actually a lot for a mono color deck and it is pretty successful.

So like mono blue is more real than I'd say it has been since M14.

So you can you can just be mono blue but most of the time that's not what's going to happen.

Most of the time blue is not going to be that open and you'll want to pair it with other colors.

You can pair it with one or more colors but I want to talk about like how like what you're looking for in different colors while staying philosophically the same like doing what blue would try to do as I envision it in this set.

So in my like first episode about Duskmourne I mentioned that like according to Wizards blue white was eerie tempo and blue black was eerie control and I speculated that that was probably kind of just like an arbitrary distinction to like claim that the archetypes were doing different things rather than anything that like super lined up with like which cards you'd want to play or like what strategies would actually be supported and to my mind that's how it's played out.

Specifically because Seized from Slumber the five mana white instant that destroys a creature and costs only two if it's destroying a tapped creature is really good and specifically really good in defensive decks.

So I like to pair white with blue primarily for trapped in the screen the common oblivion ring type thing and Seized in the slumber and I like to play blue white as a control deck as much as possible.

I've messed around with a few different like takes on blue white I've tried to be aggressive with it I've tried to lean into like playing more rooms to get more eerie triggers and I think I have my like I just have worse results the more I try to lean into any sort of real aggression or heavy synergy stuff outside of like getting I'd say specifically gremlin tamer and gremlin tamer being the blue white two mana uncommon that makes a 1/1 gremlin when you eerie or the rare that draws a card when you eerie.

I think outside of that I haven't liked playing like the room that makes a 1/1 and then can put counters on something even glimmer light's been kind of unimpressive for me in my more controlling blue white decks.

I'm really just looking to play like the blue control plan and support it with some white removal and you know any other like high rarity good white cards basically.

I'm gonna start with commons and then get to uncommons.

So black is tricky because final vengeance requires some work to support although I'm starting to think that final vengeance is good in blue black more often than I'd previously been considering as long as you can get some rooms to sacrifice to it.

It's also good if you have a lot of glimmer bursts but it's still tricky to commit to early like it's not gonna work in all decks.

Similarly murder is double black which is not always something you're gonna want.

Winter's intervention the one in black instant deal 2 to accrute your gain 2 life is fine but pretty narrow in what it can kill.

So like black offers pretty good removal but it's all kind of like hard to get into with confidence I guess.

I think that I should be playing fear of lost teeth a little bit more as that's the one mana 1/1 that when it dies deals 1 to something and you gain a life.

I think that that's like just a reasonable blocker that works well with final vengeance and also gives you like an eerie trigger.

I'm looking to draft blue black more than I have like kind of as a two color deck I think.

In red I'm basically just interested in scorching dragon fire and glassworks.

Impossible inferno is sometimes fine.

Green is kind of the trickiest because if you manifest too much you have to worry about decking yourself and you won't always have like enough creatures for monstrous emergence to be reliable.

Spine seeker centipede the 3 mana 2/1 that searches for a basic land and gets +1/+2 in vigilance if you have delirium is great but I think that like blue control and multicolor spine seeker centipede are best thought of as like two different decks even if they share a lot in common.

This is something I come back to a lot like the multicolor blue decks that I draft like I draft both multicolor blue decks and multicolor green decks but I need to think of them and approach them pretty differently or I kind of run into problems and I think that all of the manifest stuff and all of the spine seeker centipede stuff is kind of best thought of differently in the like multicolor green space and not really like you have to approach it differently than like the other blue control stuff.

So where I'm basically looking for like removal support for my blue deck green is not where I'm looking and sometimes the draft will pull me into green but when that happens I'm thinking of it as a pivot out of blue control and into whatever green deck it's putting me into.

So priority uncommons.

Blue has five great uncommons unnerving grasp the manifest bounce thing,

fear of isolation, the two mana two three flyer that picks something up,

floodgates drowner,

the two one with flash that stuns something and then you can spend one under glue and tap it to shuffle a stunned thing and it into their decks.

It has vigilance also.

Stay hidden, stay silent,

the two mana tap a thing or you can spend six mana to shuffle the thing that you tapped in and manifest and bottomless pool the room that bounces something and then has the five mana in the drus card if you damage your opponent in combat.

Incidentally stay hidden,

stay silent has better stats than unable to scream but I and my sample size is small.

I personally feel like I've had better experiences with unable to scream than stay hidden,

stay silent.

Like the fact that stay hidden,

stay silent doesn't remove static text until you can spend six mana to get rid of the creature is pretty bad and it costs an extra mana to play initially.

So I'm not very confident about thinking unable to scream is better than stay hidden,

stay silent but for my purposes I'm open to the idea that it could be.

In white I haven't loved most of white's best uncommons in this archetype.

Like gremlin tamer is fantastic but optimistic scavenger the one mana one one with eerie put a plus one plus one counter on something.

Sheltered by ghost, split skinned all,

sheltered by ghost is the aura that gives a creature plus one plus one lifelink and exiles something for until as long as that's in play.

Split skinned all the two mana two one that loots or just draws a card if you have another cruiser with power two or less.

And ethereal armor the one mana aura that gives a creature first strike and plus one plus one for each enchantment you control.

All of those are good they're all playable in this archetype.

I'm you know not often going to leave them in my sideboard sometimes an ethereal armor won't make it.

But none of them are at their best here and if you have too many of them like I often found myself getting pulled into a direction where I feel like my deck is just worse.

I'm honestly generally more interested in exercise than those other cards.

Exercise is the two mana sorcery speed removal spell that exiles a big creature or artifact or enchantment.

It's hard for me to just be like yeah all these good white uncommons don't belong here.

I mean there's some reason but also they're kind of generically good.

I don't know I do like the cards are good and I play them but I would say proceed with caution in terms of like rating them against other cards that you want that are more on plan where these things have better like win rates and if you're putting a lot of stock in their win rates I think you'd end up overvaluing a lot of these cards as far as like their strength in a blue controlling deck.

In black nowhere to run and sporogenic infection the two mana which are both two mana enchantments that kill things are the best black uncommons for the Sarcotype.

They're both very good.

Entomb if you survival it, and Dashing Bloodsucker,

the 2/5 that gets 2+0 and Lifelink when an enchantment enters.

It's kind of like a more or less complete list of black cards I'm interested in.

Fear of Infiniti- I mean,

I guess there's also like the 1/4 is pretty good.

I get questions about Fear of Infinity.

I think it's pretty good.

You end up in board stalls pretty often,

and the persistent life gain kind of makes up for the fact that it can't block.

And it's very annoying for some decks to deal with,

and you can kind of like reasonably often get it for free-ish,

where you like surveil or draw and discard and discard it.

And these blue decks have to have some kind of way to end the game,

and this is like a reasonable way to be working toward that.

And then it also plays really well if you have either of the things that draw a card when you damage your opponent,

either the Uncommon Room or the rare Enduring Curiosity.

So I've been pretty happy with that.

Unchained Bloodsucker, the 2/5 Vampire, is not a generically good card,

but I think it's good in blue/black exactly, and not all blue/black decks,

but blue/black decks with a good number of enchantments and card draw.

A lot of your- again, your blue card draw is also enchantments,

like Glimmer Burst and Drownediner.

And also the black card draw,

the black room that draws two and loses two life.

So all of the card draw is like giving you Bloodsucker triggers,

which gives you like a reasonably big creature that can end the game,

and also a pretty big life gain swing.

You can kind of think of this- like,

I have fallen into the trap of thinking of this as when it's on,

it is a 4/5 life linker, but that's not exactly true.

You can often trigger it multiple times in a turn,

especially if you don't have good attacks with a 4/5 life linker ,

you can intentionally sequence your stuff to trigger it two or three times in a turn,

and then get a very big life link attack.

So that's played pretty well for what blue/black is trying to do.

Red has a similar issue to white,

where a lot of its cards are structurally aggressive,

and a lot of its strongest uncommons are cards where you'll play them in your blue deck,

but they're off-plan enough that they're nowhere near as good as they would be in other decks,

but you're still going to put Razorkin, Hordecaller,

the 5 mana 4/4 haste that makes a 1/1 when you attack, or Piggy Bank,

the 2 mana 3/2 that dies into a treasure in your deck,

but they're off-plan and not as good as they could be.

Fear of Burning Alive and Betrayer's Bargain.

Fear of Burning Alive is the 6 mana 4/4 ETB deal for your opponent,

and then if you have Delirium whenever you deal damage to them,

you can also deal that damage to a creature,

so it can kill a creature on ETB,

and Betrayer's Bargain is the sacrifice a creature or enchantment,

or pay 2 mana deal 5.

Those are both very good.

I think the blue/red uncommons are pretty good,

like Smokey Lounge and the 2/2 that can tap and sac her room to deal 2 to your opponent and draw a card,

but I think that I've generally been pretty unhappy when I try to maximize the number of rooms I'm playing.

I feel like when I'm blue/red,

I've been overplaying the blue room that manifests and the red room that manifests.

I think that you usually don't want to lean super hard into the room thing,

but the cards will often try to convince you to.

But I think I would rather play it as a more normal blue deck with red removal and not go super hard on the room synergy stuff and maybe splash another color.

And then green, again, it has strong uncommons.

They basically all lead you down the manifest path where I think you want to just approach the deck differently if you're playing green.

Green's not a very good splash color, basically.

So the big thing to be thinking about that I usually don't like to have to think about in my control decks is what your plan is to end the game.

The idea of a finisher is an idea that I'm generally resistant to.

What's this deck's finisher?

Well, it has some creatures and some card advantage,

and I'll answer my opponent's threats and I'll kill them with whatever creatures I have.

It's just a limited deck.

It'll be fine.

In this format, it is possible largely because of manifest dread,

but also there's a lot of good card draw and removal.

You can just run out of cards and die.

Looping your deck is not trivial to do.

You have to play either multiple copies of a green uncommon,

which is not what I'm looking to do in this deck,

or have a chandelier and a way to get it back or keep it alive or something.

And playing a chandelier to begin with is a pretty high cost.

It's not a very good card.

So it's best if you can just have a coherent plan to actually kill your opponent.

And this is going to involve, like, well,

I have these decent rares that can kill an opponent.

Other times, maybe you'll have a plan to deck your opponent.

I think Scrabbling Skull Crab, the worst performing blue uncommon,

can actually be very good in these decks,

especially if you can get multiples.

They're pretty good at making sure that you deck your opponent before decking yourself.

You need to be somewhat careful about how you play them.

You don't always want to play them immediately.

You don't always want to mill your opponent early if your opponent is doing delirium stuff and you only have a moderate amount of milling available to you at the time.

But if your deck is very good at playing a defensive game and you need some way to make sure that that is going to lead to you winning rather than leading to you decking yourself,

it's a pretty reliable threat, I guess.

But yeah,

you can also just have some random land cyclers and a couple of rare or uncommon threats and there are a lot of ways to win a game of limited and I don't want to get too prescriptive with like,

"Oh,

you need this many big creatures" or "You need to play this particular card" or something.

It's more just like you do need to actually pay attention to it while you're drafting.

You need to think about like, "Okay,

how many cards do I have that can realistically win a game?

How easy are they to answer?

What happens if this one gets milled and this one gets killed?

Do I still have a plan?

Is it reliable?

Can I say like, "Oh, okay,

I'm running out of cards that I think will let me actually win the game,

but I have some countermagic so I can try to set up a spot where I play and protect one of them if I'm far enough ahead and I'm good at getting far enough ahead so that'll be fine?" There are a lot of ways to do it.

You just need to make sure that it's something you're actually paying attention to in the draft.

I also don't want to overstate it.

It's not that hard.

If you have a gremlin tamer, it's realistic to just be like, "Well,

this thing is going to make a lot of 1/1s.

There's a good chance I'll be able to kill them with that."

You don't need a ton, but you also don't want to just be like,

"Nothing but removal and card draw and not have the ability to win."

That's basically it.

I basically just listed the removal spells, but I don't know.

That's kind of the whole idea with this drafting philosophy.

In a lot of ways, it's just to say, "Yeah,

the thing that I want to be doing in general is still a thing that works in this set.

In fact,

I've been winning I think a little bit more in this set than I often do,

so it probably works better than usual in this set."

I think a lot of my losses have been when I try to, "Oh,

let's see what aggro is like in this format,"

or "Let's get weird in some way rather than doing the stuff that I want to be doing."

It's not always available.

You can't hard force this and always have it work the same way or whatever.

That covers my thoughts on this.

Now I'm going to turn it over to chat for additional questions,

so let's do that.

No new patrons to thank this week, but as always,

if you're interested in supporting the podcast,

check out patreon.com/draftingarchetypes.
